Dear Ms. Anderton:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• Indicate how continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• Be signed and dated.
A six-month provisional license is recommended. You must contest or agree to the
issuance of a provisional license in writing, on the CWL-4617 within 15 days, with
submission of the corrective action plan. If you do not submit the CWL-4617, it will be
treated as contested. Even if you contest the issuance of a provisional license, you must
still submit an acceptable corrective action plan.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Cathrine Raftery, Licensing Consultant

Type
Allegation On 07/03/2023, between the hours of 1am and 6am, there was

Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on July 5,

3

She reported she could only see Youth B from the torso up and

A felt uncomfortable, she would have moved.” She reported if she

reported she never heard anything inappropriate coming from that

reported she has not dealt with the youth being up and refusing to

Staff 1 noted there is a phone tree to call upper management if

Tour Observation:
A tour of the facility occurred on July 5, 2023, in collaboration
with the MDHHS Worker. Upon walking into the front door there
is the main dining table that Staff 1 was sitting at that faces the
milieu area. The couch where Youth A and Youth B were in line of
sight of the position where Staff 1 was sitting. To the left of the
table was the bedrooms of Youth C, Youth D, and Youth E, which
was the hallway Staff 1 would walk down per the video review. To
the right of the table is the hallway where Youth A’s bedroom is
and where Youth B’s bathroom was prior to him moving. During
the tour, the staff binder was reviewed which had the peer
boundary plan for Youth A located in it.
Documents Reviewed
- Facility Youth Supervision Procedure with the most recent
revision date of June 2022- Staff is responsible for the direct
supervision of youth living in the house in which they are working.
To ensure appropriate supervision, staff responsible for youth
must: maintain visual contact and monitoring of the youth; know
where each youth is at all times; be physically present in close
proximity to the youth; clearly communicate when the supervision
of youth transfers to another staff person; ensure hallways are
8

being monitored at all times when youth are in their rooms, den,
bathrooms, laundry room, common hallway space or med cart
area. If a staff member must leave their post as the direct
supervisor of the hallway, they will notify another staff to take over
this supervision.
- Facility Youth Development Specialist Procedures with the
most recent revision date of February 2022- The purpose of the
policy is to ensure staff understand their role and responsibilities
while working at the facility. It notes, “Interactions with youth must
be trauma responsible. Interactions with youth are expected to be
appropriate, respectful and should be focused on supporting
youth. Staff will maintain clear and appropriate boundaries. This
includes personal boundaries and not allowing youth to violate
personable boundaries such as personal space or engaging in
personal conversations where the purpose of sharing information
is not benefit to the youth. While working, staff are expected to be
actively engaged with the youth and not spending their time
talking, texting, or engaging with their phone. Staff are expected to
provide supervision to youth according to the Supervisor
procedures and/or precautions/status paperwork. Supervision is
most easily achieve when engaged with youth and completing
activities with them.”
- Youth A’s Peer Boundary Safety Plan dated 04/12/2023 and
updated on 06/22/2023- This safety plan notes Youth A has a
peer boundary issue. It notes “Staff should stand and/or sit
between and redirect all inappropriate conversation and boundary
concerns with all peers. This precaution will be in place for an
extended period of time.” This safety plan was emailed out to all
residential staff on 04/12/2023. This consultant did review the
email showing it went to all direct care staff from the clinical team.
- Facility Daily Observation Forms for Youth A, Youth B,
Youth C, Youth D, and Youth E date 7/3/203- Daily Observation
Forms for all five youth were reviewed that were completed by
Staff 1. The forms noted Youth A and Youth B being out in the
milieu from 1am to about 7am on 07/03/23. The documentation
noted Staff 1 completed room checks consistent with the video
review. Staff 1 did complete the room checks in variable intervals
not exceeding fifteen minutes.
- Human Resource File for Staff 1- On 06/07/2023, Staff 1 was
put on a corrective action due to video footage being reviewed
that found Staff 1 missed some bedroom checks. This occurred on
05/17/2023 when Staff 1 was working at Renucci home where the
9

allegations occurred. Staff 1 completed supervision with Staff 1 on
06/26/23 and 07/03/23 to review the supervision policy. Staff 1
was up to date on all of her training requirements. On 06/29/2023,
Staff 1 completed a training that reviewed the supervision policy.
On 05/18/2023, Staff 1 completed the training residential
supervision scenario training with role play.
- Special Investigation #2023C0000388- This investigation was
assigned on 04/12/2023 due to concerns of staff losing
supervision of a youth thinking she went AWOL but was found to
be hiding in a vacant room. The investigation found CCI Rule
400.4109 (1)(c) was found to be in non-compliance due to staff
not following the supervision policy of the facility and CCI Rule
400.4127 (4) was found to be in non-compliance as staff were
completing bedroom checks on the fifteen-minute mark and no in
variable intervals. The facility had to complete a corrective action
plan to come into compliance.
- Special Investigation #2023C0000393 – This investigation was
assigned on 4/14/2023 due to concerns of a youth engaging in
self-harm causing injury to her arm when staff were supposed to
be having heightened supervision of the youth. The investigation
found CCI Rule 400.4126 (1) in not compliance as staff did not
comply with the requirement of heightened supervision of the
youth allowing them to harm themselves. CCI Rule 400.4142 (1)
(d) was found to be in non-compliance as staff had left the
medication room door open, which left the medication cart
accessible to all the youth in the home. CCI Rule 400.4127 (1)
was found to be in non-compliance as it found staff were not doing
the variable interval bedroom checks. Public Act 116-722.120 was
found to be in noncompliance as staff falsified documentation
regarding interval checks of supervision on the observation log of
the youth. CCI Rule 400.412 (4)(a) was found to be in
noncompliance as MDHHS Worker found a preponderance of
evidence for improper supervision which resulted in a confirmed
case for a staff member. The facility had to complete a corrective
action plan to come into compliance.
- Special Investigation #2023C0000459- This investigation was
assigned on 05/15/2023 due to concerns of a youth wrapping a
cord around her neck and staff not having appropriate supervision.
CCI Rule 400.4127 (1) was found to be in non-compliance as it
found staff were not engaged in variable interval checks on the
youth when the youth was sleeping or awake. Documentation
showed there were several gaps of time failure to provide
10

appropriate emergency medical care which resulted in a
confirmed case for a staff member.
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance due to Staff 1 not following
the facility’s general supervision policy or Youth A’s peer boundary
safety plan. Within the investigation it was found to be true that
Youth A and Youth B were inappropriately touching one another
on the couch within the facility milieu area for several hours in the
middle of the night. Staff 1 was in charge of supervising the youth
and did acknowledge the youth were not supposed to be up but
did not see a concern of the youth sitting with one another on the
couch.
Technical Assistance:
Although the facility reacts appropriately when they have identified
issues with staff supervision, trained staff continue to not provide
the required supervision that has led to youth being able to self-
harm, have access to medication rooms, and to engage in sexual
relations. It was recommended to have a longer period of
mentorship for newer staff on all shifts so that there is an increase
level of support and oversight.
Facility needs to update procedures related to supervision
including peer boundaries to address communication of
supervision, safety plans, peer boundary plans with staff and
verification they received the information.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
